title: 104_s2039
content: The Act of 1996 is titled the "Perkins County Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purposes. The Congress finds insufficient water supplies of reasonable quality for Perkins County Rural Water System in South Dakota, posing a threat to public health. The Southwest Pipeline project was authorized for Federal cost share participation in 1986. The Congress recognizes the Perkins County Rural Water System as part of the Southwest Pipeline Project, providing safe water supply from the Missouri River. The purpose is to ensure a reliable water supply for members in Perkins County, South Dakota. The Perkins County Rural Water System in South Dakota aims to develop safe water supplies for municipal, rural, and industrial use, as well as promote water conservation programs. The Perkins County Rural Water System in South Dakota aims to develop safe water supplies for municipal, rural, and industrial use, as well as promote water conservation programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms related to the feasibility study, project construction budget, and pumping and operational requirements for the Perkins County Rural Water System. The Perkins County Rural Water System delivers water to retail entities for distribution to individual users. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "water supply system" pertains to the Perkins County Rural Water System, Inc., established in accordance with a feasibility study. Federal assistance is provided for the water supply system. The Secretary can grant funds to Perkins County Rural Water System for planning and constructing a water supply system in Perkins County, South Dakota. The system will provide safe water supplies for municipal, rural, and industrial use, wetlands mitigation, and water conservation. Grants cannot exceed the authorized amount, and construction funds are contingent on meeting environmental requirements and preparing an engineering report. The Secretary can grant funds for a water supply system in Perkins County, South Dakota. A final engineering report must be submitted to Congress before construction begins, and a water conservation program must be implemented. SEC. 5. WATER CONSERVATION. The water conservation program aims to promote the use of best technology and management practices to conserve water. It includes standards for plumbing fixtures, leak detection, rate structures, public education, and coordination between water systems. The water conservation program includes standards for plumbing fixtures, leak detection, rate structures, public education, and coordination between water systems. The programs described in subsection (b) shall contain provisions for periodic review and revision in cooperation with the Secretary. Mitigation of fish and wildlife losses for the Perkins County Rural Water Supply System will be based on ecological equivalency and conducted concurrently with project construction. The use of Pick-Sloan power is also authorized. The Western Area Power Administration will provide capacity and energy for irrigation and drainage pumping for the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program from May 1 to October 31 each year. The water supply system must operate on a not-for-profit basis and purchase its electric service from a qualified preference power supplier that buys power from the Western Area Power Administration. The Western Area Power Administration will provide capacity and energy for irrigation and drainage pumping for the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program. The rate schedule for the power will be based on the firm power rate schedule of the Pick-Sloan Eastern Division. A contract will be agreed upon by the Administration, power suppliers, and the Perkins County Rural Water System, Inc. to pass through the benefit of the rate schedule to the water system. The power supplier shall pass through the benefits of the rate schedule to the water supply system, allowing for customary charges to be included in the electric service charges. SEC. 8. NO LIMITATION ON WATER PROJECTS IN STATES. This Act does not restrict water projects in South Dakota and North Dakota authorized under existing law. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS. This Act does not affect State water law, interstate compacts, water rights, or water quality laws. SEC. 10. FEDERAL COST SHARE. SEC. 10. FEDERAL COST SHARE. The Secretary can provide funds equal to 75% of the project construction budget for the water supply system under section 4, and cover increases in development costs. SEC. 11. NON-FEDERAL COST SHARE. The non-Federal share of costs for the water supply system is 25% of the project construction budget and covers increases in development costs. SEC. 12. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION AUTHORIZATION. SEC. 12. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION AUTHORIZATION. The Secretary authorizes the Bureau of Reclamation to oversee construction of the water supply system in specified areas. The Bureau's funds for planning and construction cannot exceed 3% of the total project budget for the portion in Perkins County, South Dakota. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $15,000,000 is authorized for planning and construction of the water system under section 4, with additional funds for cost increases after May 1, 1994.
